definition: SILAC (Stable Isotope Labeling by/with Amino acids in Cell culture) is a technique based on mass spectrometry that detects differences in protein abundance among samples using non-radioactive isotopic labeling. It is a popular method for quantitative proteomics.
The reason for performing the assay
A shortened name of an assay, often abbreviated from the full title to fit within a limited number of characters

The Transfluor assay employs a beta-arrestin-GFP fusion protein to detect activation of GPCRs: Upon ligand binding the GPCR, cytosolic arrestin-GFP quickly translocates to the cell membrane and then to endocytic vesicles, where it 'clusters' and can be detected by fluorescent image analysis. (Developed / commercialized by Norak, then Molecular Devices)

PathHunter Cell-Based Kinase Assays, avaliable for hundreds of kinases, are functional, cell-based assays that employ enzyme fragment complementation (two fragments of the beta-galactosidase enzyme). Each inactive fragment is fused to a different protein (e.g., a tyrosine kinase and its receptor), such that interaxtions between the two proteins drives complementation between the two fragments, resulting in active beta-galactosidase, which cleaves a substrate to generate chemiluminescent signal.
An interaction between DNA (single- or double-stranded) and a small molecule (e.g., hormone, organic compound with a low molecular weight (<800 Da)).
An interaction between any RNA (such as mRNA, tRNA, rRNA, miRNA, lincRNA, synthetic RNA) and a small molecule (e.g., hormone, organic compound with a low molecular weight (<800 Da)).

A titer (or titre) is a measure of concentration. A viral titer assay is any method to quantify the number of viruses in a specific volume. Common methods include a plaque formation assay (PFA), focus forming assay (FFA), which yield results of plaque or focus forming units per ml (pfu or ffu/ ml), or endpoint dilution assay (TCID50, which measures the amount of virus needed to kill 50% 0of infected hosts or cells).  TCID50 and pfu/ml results are not equivalent.

Serum is the blood fraction remaining after the natural coagulation of blood, followed by centrifugation to remove any remaining red blood cells. Serum is thought to provide basic elements required for cell culture, including growth factors, attachment factors, iron transporters, vitamins, amino acids, lipids, carbohydrates, hormones, and trace elements. Fetal bovine serum (FBS), also called fetal calf serum (FCS), comes from the blood drawn from a bovine (cow) fetus via a closed system of collection at the slaughterhouse. FBS/FCS is the most widely used serum-supplement for the in vitro cell culture of eukaryotic cells. This is due to it having a very low level of antibodies and containing more growth factors, allowing for versatility in many different cell culture applications. Serum contains many factors that are not
 controlled for, which can have a direct or indirect effect on the cells in culture, thus creating significant variability between suppliers and lots from a single supplier. Different methods, such as heat inactivation or dialysis, are sometimes used to eliminate undesired components (such as labile growth factors, vitamins, etc. or the complement system). Some suppliers test serum for the presence of other factors such as tetracylcine or mycoplasma.
AMC is an abbreviation for 7-Amino-4-methylcoumarin, is a chromophore for enzyme substrates. A synonym is coumarin 120
EDANS (5-((2-Aminoethyl)amino)naphthalene-1-sulfonic acid) is a common donor for developing FRET-based nucleic acid probes and protease substrates. EDANS is often paired with DABCYL or DABSYL.
MCA is an abbreviation for methoxycoumarin, or 7-Methoxycoumarin-4-acetic acid, commonly used as a fluorescent label for peptides.
MDC is an abbreviation for monodansyl cadaverine (aka dansylcadaverine), an autofluorescent dye commonly used to monitor autophagy
Involves the use of a unicellular living organism such as bacteria or yeast--but not cell lines derived from multicellular organisms.
Involves the use of a multicellular living organism, such as C. elegans (nematode), Drosophila (fruitfly), zebrafish, mouse, etc. This would encompass all in vivo studies.

U937 cells stably transfected with and expressing the surface displayed fusion protein of FAP (fluorogen activating protein) AM2.2 to the extracellular N-terminus of the human β2AR gene  (thus, 'AM2.2-beta2AR'). See PMCID: PMC3621705

U937 cells stably transfected with and expressing both the surface displayed fusion protein of FAP (fluorogen activating protein) AM2.2 to the extracellular N-terminus of the human β2AR (AM2.2-beta2AR) and the surface displayed fusion protein of FAP MG13 to the extracellular N-terminus of the murine CCR5 . See PMCID: PMC3621705
U937 cells stably transfected with and expressing the surface displayed fusion protein of FAP (fluorogen activating protein) MG13 to the extracellular N-terminus of murine CCRF. See PMCID: PMC3621705
U937 cells stably transfected with and expressing the surface displayed fusion protein of FAP (fluorogen activating protein) AM2.2 to GPR32. See PMCID: PMC3621705

PAMPA (parallel artificial membrane permeability assay) is a method which determines the permeability of substances from a donor compartment, through a lipid-infused artificial membrane into an acceptor compartment. It is used as an in vitro model of passive, transcellular permeation to predict oral absorption. PAMPA is an alternative to the cell-based Caco-2 permeability assay: Caco-2 uses compartments of different volumes separated by a monolayer of cells grown on a filter. PAMPA, however, uses chambers of the same size, separated by a filter coated with lipid in organic solvent.
A compound or extract derived from a living organism.

A data collection method that entails measurements of an entire population of cells.
A data collection method that entails measurements from only a single cell.

Involves the use of living cells of eukaryotic origin, derived from a multicellular organism, and is a heterogeneous assay type.  Typically, this refers to permanent (immortal) cell lines, or primary cells, or some form of stem cells. This is distinct from a single-celled organism-based format (classically bacteria or yeast).
Involves the use of a living organism, either single or multi-celled, and is a heterogeneous assay type.

The CellTiter-Fluor Cell Viability Assay measures the relative number of viable cells in a population. The assay is based on measurement of a conserved and constitutive protease activity within live cells and therefore serves as a biomarker of cell viability. The live-cell protease activity is restricted to intact viable cells and is measured using a fluorogenic, cell-permeant, peptide substrate (Gly-Phe-AFC). The substrate enters intact cells, where it is cleaved by the live-cell protease activity to generate a fluorescent signal proportional to the number of living cells. The live-cell protease becomes inactive upon loss of membrane integrity and leakage into the surrounding culture medium. (description adapted from vendor Promega)

The Tox21 compound collection is a library of approximately 10,000 (10K) environmental chemicals and drugs (~10,500 chemicals (~8,300 unique)), also referred to as the 'Tox21 10K library'. Several publications, from NCATS and EPA.  See also https://www.epa.gov/chemical-research/toxicology-testing-21st-century-tox21 or https://ncats.nih.gov/tox21/about/operations.
